00043 # "standard" WeBWorK date/time format (for set definition files):
00044 #     %m/%d/%y at %I:%M%P
00045 # where:
00046 #     %m = month number, starting with 01
00047 #     %d = numeric day of the month, with leading zeros (eg 01..31)
00048 #     %Y = year (4 digits)
00049 #     %I = hour, 12 hour clock, leading 0's)
00050 #     %M = minute, leading 0's
00051 #     %P = am or pm (Yes %p and %P are backwards :)
00052 use constant DATE_FORMAT => "%m/%d/%Y at %I:%M%P %Z";
00053

00100 # This is like use, except it happens at runtime. You have to quote the module name and put a
00101 # comma after it if you're specifying an import list. Also, to specify an empty import list (as
00102 # opposed to no import list) use an empty arrayref instead of an empty array.
00103 # 
00104 #   use Xyzzy;               =>    runtime_use "Xyzzy";
00105 #   use Foo qw/pine elm/;    =>    runtime_use "Foo", qw/pine elm/;
00106 #   use Foo::Bar ();         =>    runtime_use "Foo::Bar", [];
00107 
00108 sub runtime_use($;@) {
00109     my ($module, @import_list) = @_;
00110     my $package = (caller)[0]; # import into caller's namespace
00111     
00112     my $import_string;
00113     if (@import_list == 1 and ref $import_list[0] eq "ARRAY" and @{$import_list[0]} == 0) {
00114         $import_string = "";
00115     } else {
00116         # \Q = quote metachars \E = end quoting
00117         $import_string = "import $module " . join(",", map { qq|"\Q$_\E"| } @import_list);
00118     }
00119     eval "package $package; require $module; $import_string";
00120     die $@ if $@;
00121 }

00149 # Convert Windows and Mac (classic) line endings to UNIX line endings in a string.
00150 # Windows uses CRLF, Mac uses CR, UNIX uses LF. (CR is ASCII 15, LF if ASCII 12)
00151 sub force_eoln($) {
00152     my ($string) = @_;
00153     $string =~ s/\015\012?/\012/g;
00154     return $string;
00155 }
00156 
00157 sub readFile($) {
00158     my $fileName = shift;
00159     local $/ = undef; # slurp the whole thing into one string
00160     open my $dh, "<", $fileName
00161         or die "failed to read file $fileName: $!";
00162     my $result = <$dh>;
00163     close $dh;
00164     return force_eoln($result);
00165 }
00166 
00167 sub readDirectory($) {
00168     my $dirName = shift;
00169     opendir my $dh, $dirName
00170         or die "Failed to read directory $dirName: $!";
00171     my @result = readdir $dh;
00172     close $dh;
00173     return @result;
00174 }
00175 
00176 =item @matches = listFilesRecusive($dir, $match_qr, $prune_qr, $match_full, $prune_full)
00177 
00178 Traverses the directory tree rooted at $dir, returning a list of files, named
00179 pipes, and sockets matching the regular expression $match_qr. Directories
00180 matching the regular expression $prune_qr are not visited.
00181 
00182 $match_full and $prune_full are boolean values that indicate whether $match_qr
00183 and $prune_qr, respectively, should be applied to the bare directory entry
00184 (false) or to the path to the directory entry relative to $dir.
00185 
00186 @matches is a list of paths relative to $dir.
00187 
00188 =cut
00189 
00190 sub listFilesRecursiveHelper($$$$$$);
00191 sub listFilesRecursive($;$$$$) {
00192     my ($dir, $match_qr, $prune_qr, $match_full, $prune_full) = @_;
00193     return listFilesRecursiveHelper($dir, "", $match_qr, $prune_qr, $match_full, $prune_full);
00194 }
00195 
00196 sub listFilesRecursiveHelper($$$$$$) {
00197     my ($base_dir, $curr_dir, $match_qr, $prune_qr, $match_full, $prune_full) = @_;
00198     
00199     my $full_dir = "$base_dir/$curr_dir";
00200     
00201     my @dir_contents = readDirectory($full_dir);
00202     
00203     my @matches;
00204     
00205     foreach my $dir_entry (@dir_contents) {
00206         my $full_path = "$full_dir/$dir_entry";
00207         
00208         # determine whether the entry is a directory or a file, taking into account the 
00209         my $is_dir;
00210         my $is_file;
00211         if (-l $full_path) {
00212             my $link_target = "$full_dir/" . readlink $full_path;
00213             if ($link_target) {
00214                 $is_dir = -d $link_target;
00215                 $is_file = !$is_dir && -f $link_target || -p $link_target || -S $link_target;
00216             } else {
00217                 warn "Couldn't resolve symlink $full_path: $!";
00218             }
00219         } else {
00220             $is_dir = -d $full_path;
00221             $is_file = !$is_dir && -f $full_path || -p $full_path || -S $full_path;
00222         }
00223         
00224         if ($is_dir) {
00225             # standard things to skip
00226             next if $dir_entry eq ".";
00227             next if $dir_entry eq "..";
00228             
00229             # skip unreadable directories (and broken symlinks, incidentally)
00230             unless (-r $full_path) {
00231                 warn "Directory/symlink $full_path not readable";
00232                 next;
00233             }
00234             
00235             # check $prune_qr
00236             my $subdir = ($curr_dir eq "") ? $dir_entry : "$curr_dir/$dir_entry";
00237             if (defined $prune_qr) {
00238                 my $prune_string = $prune_full ? $subdir : $dir_entry;
00239                 next if $prune_string =~ m/$prune_qr/;
00240             }
00241             
00242             # everything looks good, time to recurse!
00243             push @matches, listFilesRecursiveHelper($base_dir, $subdir, $match_qr, $prune_qr, $match_full, $prune_full);
00244         } elsif ($is_file) {
00245             my $file = ($curr_dir eq "") ? $dir_entry : "$curr_dir/$dir_entry";
00246             my $match_string = $match_full ? $file : $dir_entry;
00247             if (not defined $match_string or $match_string =~ m/$match_qr/) {
00248                 push @matches, $file;
00249             }
00250         } else {
00251             # otherwise, it's a character device or a block device, and i don't
00252             # suppose we want anything to do with those ;-)
00253         }
00254     }
00255     
00256     return @matches;
00257 }
00258 
00259 # A very useful macro for making sure that all of the directories to a file have
00260 # been constructed.
00261 sub surePathToFile($$) {
00262     # constructs intermediate directories enroute to the file 
00263     # the input path must be the path relative to this starting directory
00264     my $start_directory = shift;
00265     my $path = shift;
00266     my $delim = "/"; 
00267     unless ($start_directory and $path ) {
00268         warn "missing directory<br> surePathToFile  start_directory   path ";
00269         return '';
00270     }
00271     # use the permissions/group on the start directory itself as a template
00272     my ($perms, $groupID) = (stat $start_directory)[2,5];
00273     #warn "&urePathToTmpFile: perms=$perms groupID=$groupID\n";
00274     
00275     # if the path starts with $start_directory (which is permitted but optional) remove this initial segment
00276     $path =~ s|^$start_directory|| if $path =~ m|^$start_directory|;
00277 
00278     
00279     # find the nodes on the given path
00280         my @nodes = split("$delim",$path);
00281     
00282     # create new path
00283     $path = $start_directory; #convertPath("$tmpDirectory");
00284     
00285     while (@nodes>1) {  # the last node is the file name
00286         $path = $path . shift (@nodes) . "/"; #convertPath($path . shift (@nodes) . "/");
00287         #FIXME  this make directory command may not be fool proof.
00288         unless (-e $path) {
00289             mkdir($path, $perms)
00290                 or warn "Failed to create directory $path with start directory $start_directory ";
00291         }
00292 
00293     }
00294     
00295     $path = $path . shift(@nodes); #convertPath($path . shift(@nodes));
00296     return $path;
00297 }
00298 
00299 sub makeTempDirectory($$) {
00300     my ($parent, $basename) = @_;
00301     # Loop until we're able to create a directory, or it fails for some
00302     # reason other than there already being something there.
00303     my $triesRemaining = MKDIR_ATTEMPTS;
00304     my ($fullPath, $success);
00305     do {
00306         my $suffix = join "", map { ('A'..'Z','a'..'z','0'..'9')[int rand 62] } 1 .. 8;
00307         $fullPath = "$parent/$basename.$suffix";
00308         $success = mkdir $fullPath;
00309     } until ($success or not $!{EEXIST});
00310     die "Failed to create directory $fullPath: $!"
00311         unless $success;
00312     return $fullPath;
00313 }
00314 
00315 sub removeTempDirectory($) {
00316     my ($dir) = @_;
00317     rmtree($dir, 0, 0);
00318 }
00319 
00320 =item path_is_subdir($path, $dir, $allow_relative)
00321 
00322 Ensures that $path refers to a location "inside" $dir. If $allow_relative is
00323 true and $path is not absoulte, it is assumed to be relative to $dir.
00324 
00325 The method of checking is rather rudimentary at the moment. First, upreferences
00326 ("..") are disallowed, in $path, then it is checked to make sure that some
00327 prefix of it matches $dir.
00328 
00329 If either of these checks fails, a false value is returned. Otherwise, a true
00330 value is returned.
00331 
00332 =cut
00333 
00334 sub path_is_subdir($$;$) {
00335     my ($path, $dir, $allow_relative) = @_;
00336     
00337     unless ($path =~ /^\//) {
00338         if ($allow_relative) {
00339             $path = "$dir/$path";
00340         } else {
00341             return 0;
00342         }
00343     }
00344     
00345     $path = File::Spec->canonpath($path);
00346     $path .= "/" unless $path =~ m|/$|;
00347     return 0 if $path =~ m#(^\.\.$|^\.\./|/\.\./|/\.\.$)#;
00348     
00349     $dir = File::Spec->canonpath($dir);
00350     $dir .= "/" unless $dir =~ m|/$|;
00351     return 0 unless $path =~ m|^$dir|;
00352     
00353     return 1;
00354 }
00355 
00356 =back

00360 ################################################################################
00361 # Date/time processing
00362 ################################################################################
00363 
00364 =head2 Date/time processing
00365 
00366 =over
00367 
00368 =item $dateTime = parseDateTime($string, $display_tz)
00369 
00370 Parses $string as a datetime. If $display_tz is given, $string is assumed to be
00371 in that timezone. Otherwise, the server's timezone is used. The result,
00372 $dateTime, is an integer UNIX datetime (epoch) in the server's timezone.
00373 
00374 =cut
00375 
00376 # This is a modified version of the subroutine of the same name from WeBWorK
00377 # 1.9.05's scripts/FILE.pl (v1.13). It has been modified to understand time
00378 # zones. The time zone specification must appear at the end of the string and be
00379 # preceded by whitespace. The return value is a list consisting of the following
00380 # elements:
00381 # 
00382 #     ($second, $minute, $hour, $day, $month, $year, $zone)
00383 # 
00384 # $second, $minute, $hour, $day, and $month are zero-indexed. $year is the
00385 # number of years since 1900. $zone is a string (hopefully) representing the
00386 # time zone.
00387 # 
00388 # Error handling has also been improved. Exceptions are now thrown for errors,
00389 # and more information is given about the nature of errors.
00390 # 
00391 sub unformatDateAndTime {
00392     my ($string) = @_;
00393     my $orgString = $string;
00394     
00395     $string =~ s|^\s+||;
00396     $string =~ s|\s+$||;
00397     $string =~ s|at| at |i; ## OK if forget to enter spaces or use wrong case
00398     $string =~ s|AM| AM|i;  ## OK if forget to enter spaces or use wrong case
00399     $string =~ s|PM| PM|i;  ## OK if forget to enter spaces or use wrong case
00400     $string =~ s|,| at |;   ## start translating old form of date/time to new form
00401     
00402     # case where the at is missing: MM/DD/YYYY at HH:MM AMPM ZONE
00403     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "The 'at' appears to be missing.")
00404         if $string =~ m|^\s*[\/\d]+\s+[:\d]+|;
00405     
00406     my ($date, $at, $time, $AMPM, $TZ) = split /\s+/, $string;
00407     
00408     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "The date and/or time appear to be missing.", $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ)
00409         unless defined $date and defined $at and defined $time;
00410     
00411     # deal with military time
00412     unless ($time =~ /:/) {
00413         {  ##bare block for 'case" structure
00414             $time =~ /(\d\d)(\d\d)/;
00415             my $tmp_hour = $1;
00416             my $tmp_min = $2;
00417             if ($tmp_hour eq '00') {$time = "12:$tmp_min"; $AMPM = 'AM';last;}
00418             if ($tmp_hour eq '12') {$time = "12:$tmp_min"; $AMPM = 'PM';last;}
00419             if ($tmp_hour < 12) {$time = "$tmp_hour:$tmp_min"; $AMPM = 'AM';last;}
00420             if ($tmp_hour < 24) {
00421                 $tmp_hour = $tmp_hour - 12;
00422                 $time = "$tmp_hour:$tmp_min";
00423                 $AMPM = 'PM';
00424             }
00425         }  ##end of bare block for 'case" structure
00426 
00427     }
00428     
00429     # default value for $AMPM
00430     $AMPM = "AM" unless defined $AMPM;
00431     
00432     my ($mday, $mon, $year, $wday, $yday, $sec, $pm, $min, $hour);
00433     $sec=0;
00434     $time =~ /^([0-9]+)\s*\:\s*([0-9]*)/;
00435     $min=$2;
00436     $hour = $1;
00437     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "Hour must be in the range [1,12].", $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ)
00438         if $hour < 1 or $hour > 12;
00439     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "Minute must be in the range [0-59].", $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ)
00440         if $min < 0 or $min > 59;
00441     $pm = 0;
00442     $pm = 12 if ($AMPM =~/PM/ and $hour < 12);
00443     $hour += $pm;
00444     $hour = 0 if ($AMPM =~/AM/ and $hour == 12);
00445     $date =~  m|([0-9]+)\s*/\s*([0-9]+)/\s*([0-9]+)|;
00446     $mday =$2;
00447     $mon=($1-1);
00448     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "Day must be in the range [1,31].", $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ)
00449         if $mday < 1 or $mday > 31;
00450     unformatDateAndTime_error($orgString, "Month must be in the range [1,12].", $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ)
00451         if $mon < 0 or $mon > 11;
00452     $year=$3;
00453     $wday="";
00454     $yday="";
00455     return ($sec, $min, $hour, $mday, $mon, $year, $TZ);
00456 }
00457 
00458 sub unformatDateAndTime_error {
00459     
00460     if (@_ > 2) {
00461         my ($orgString, $error, $date, $time, $AMPM, $TZ) = @_;
00462         $date = "(undefined)" unless defined $date;
00463         $time = "(undefined)" unless defined $time;
00464         $AMPM = "(undefined)" unless defined $AMPM;
00465         $TZ   = "(undefined)" unless defined $TZ;
00466         die "Incorrect date/time format \"$orgString\": $error\n",
00467             "Correct format is MM/DD/YY at HH:MM AMPM ZONE\n",
00468             "\tdate = $date\n",
00469             "\ttime = $time\n",
00470             "\tampm = $AMPM\n",
00471             "\tzone = $TZ\n";
00472     } else {
00473         my ($orgString, $error) = @_;
00474         die "Incorrect date/time format \"$orgString\": $error\n",
00475             "Correct format is MM/DD/YY at HH:MM AMPM ZONE\n";
00476     }
00477 }
00478 
00479 sub parseDateTime($;$) {
00480     my ($string, $display_tz) = @_;
00481     warn "time zone not defined".caller() unless defined($display_tz);
00482     $display_tz ||= "local";
00483 
00484 
00485     # use WeBWorK 1 date parsing routine
00486     my ($second, $minute, $hour, $day, $month, $year, $zone) = unformatDateAndTime($string);
00487     my $zone_str = defined $zone ? $zone : "UNDEF";
00488     #warn "\tunformatDateAndTime: $second $minute $hour $day $month $year $zone_str\n";
00489     
00490     # DateTime expects month 1-12, not 0-11
00491     $month++;
00492     
00493     # Do what Time::Local does to ambiguous years
00494     {
00495         my $ThisYear     = (localtime())[5]; # FIXME: should be relative to $string's timezone
00496         my $Breakpoint   = ($ThisYear + 50) % 100;
00497         my $NextCentury  = $ThisYear - $ThisYear % 100;
00498            $NextCentury += 100 if $Breakpoint < 50;
00499         my $Century      = $NextCentury - 100;
00500         my $SecOff       = 0;
00501         
00502         if ($year >= 1000) {
00503             # leave alone
00504         } elsif ($year < 100 and $year >= 0) {
00505             $year += ($year > $Breakpoint) ? $Century : $NextCentury;
00506             $year += 1900;
00507         } else {
00508             $year += 1900;
00509         }
00510     }
00511     
00512     my $epoch;
00513     
00514     if (defined $zone and $zone ne "") {
00515         if (DateTime::TimeZone->is_valid_name($zone)) {
00516             #warn "\t\$zone is valid according to DateTime::TimeZone\n";
00517             
00518             my $dt = new DateTime(
00519                 year      => $year,
00520                 month     => $month,
00521                 day       => $day,
00522                 hour      => $hour,
00523                 minute    => $minute,
00524                 second    => $second,
00525                 time_zone => $zone,
00526             );
00527             #warn "\t\$dt = ", $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT), "\n";
00528             
00529             $epoch = $dt->epoch;
00530             #warn "\t\$dt->epoch = $epoch\n";
00531         } else {
00532             #warn "\t\$zone is invalid according to DateTime::TimeZone, so we ask Time::Zone\n";
00533             
00534             # treat the date/time as UTC
00535             my $dt = new DateTime(
00536                 year      => $year,
00537                 month     => $month,
00538                 day       => $day,
00539                 hour      => $hour,
00540                 minute    => $minute,
00541                 second    => $second,
00542                 time_zone => "UTC",
00543             );
00544             #warn "\t\$dt = ", $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT), "\n";
00545             
00546             # convert to an epoch value
00547             my $utc_epoch = $dt->epoch
00548                 or die "Date/time '$string' not representable as an epoch. Get more bits!\n";
00549             #warn "\t\$utc_epoch = $utc_epoch\n";
00550             
00551             # get offset for supplied timezone and utc_epoch
00552             my $offset = tz_offset($zone, $utc_epoch) or die "Time zone '$zone' not recognized.\n";
00553             #warn "\t\$zone is valid according to Time::Zone (\$offset = $offset)\n";
00554             
00555             #$epoch = $utc_epoch + $offset;
00556             ##warn "\t\$epoch = \$utc_epoch + \$offset = $epoch\n";
00557             
00558             $dt->subtract(seconds => $offset);
00559             #warn "\t\$dt - \$offset = ", $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT), "\n";
00560             
00561             $epoch = $dt->epoch;
00562             #warn "\t\$epoch = $epoch\n";
00563         }
00564     } else {
00565         #warn "\t\$zone not supplied, using \$display_tz\n";
00566         
00567         my $dt = new DateTime(
00568             year      => $year,
00569             month     => $month,
00570             day       => $day,
00571             hour      => $hour,
00572             minute    => $minute,
00573             second    => $second,
00574             time_zone => $display_tz,
00575         );
00576         #warn "\t\$dt = ", $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT), "\n";
00577         
00578         $epoch = $dt->epoch;
00579         #warn "\t\$epoch = $epoch\n";
00580     }
00581     
00582     return $epoch;
00583 }
00584 
00585 =item $string = formatDateTime($dateTime, $display_tz)
00586 
00587 Formats the UNIX datetime $dateTime in the standard WeBWorK datetime format.
00588 $dateTime is assumed to be in the server's time zone. If $display_tz is given,
00589 the datetime is converted from the server's timezone to the timezone specified.
00590 
00591 =cut
00592 
00593 sub formatDateTime($;$) {
00594     my ($dateTime, $display_tz) = @_;
00595     warn "Utils::formatDateTime is not a method. ", join(" ",caller(2)) if ref($dateTime); # catch bad calls to Utils::formatDateTime
00596     warn "not defined formatDateTime('$dateTime', '$display_tz') ",join(" ",caller(2)) unless  $display_tz;
00597     $dateTime = $dateTime ||0;  # do our best to provide default values
00598     $display_tz ||= "local";    # do our best to provide default vaules
00599     
00600     my $dt = DateTime->from_epoch(epoch => $dateTime, time_zone => $display_tz);
00601     #warn "\t\$dt = ", $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT), "\n";
00602     return $dt->strftime(DATE_FORMAT);
00603 }
00604 
00605 =item $string = textDateTime($string_or_dateTime)
00606 
00607 Accepts a UNIX datetime or a formatted string, returns a formatted string.
00608 
00609 =cut
00610 
00611 sub textDateTime($) {
00612     return ($_[0] =~ m/^\d*$/) ? formatDateTime($_[0]) : $_[0];
00613 }
00614 
00615 =item $dateTIme = intDateTime($string_or_dateTime)
00616 
00617 Accepts a UNIX datetime or a formatted string, returns a UNIX datetime.
00618 
00619 =cut
00620 
00621 sub intDateTime($) {
00622     return ($_[0] =~ m/^\d*$/) ?  $_[0] : parseDateTime($_[0]);
00623 }
00624 
00625 =item $timeinsec = timeToSec($time)
00626 
00627 Makes a stab at converting a time (with a possible unit) into a number of 
00628 seconds.  
00629 
00630 =cut
00631 
00632 sub timeToSec($) {
00633     my $t = shift();
00634     if ( $t =~ /^(\d+)\s+(\S+)\s*$/ ) {
00635     my ( $val, $unit ) = ( $1, $2 );
00636     if ( $unit =~ /month/i || $unit =~ /mon/i ) {
00637         $val *= 18144000;  # this assumes 30 days/month
00638     } elsif ( $unit =~ /week/i || $unit =~ /wk/i ) {
00639         $val *= 604800;
00640     } elsif ( $unit =~ /day/i || $unit =~ /dy/i ) {
00641         $val *= 86400;
00642     } elsif ( $unit =~ /hour/i || $unit =~ /hr/i ) {
00643         $val *= 3600;
00644     } elsif ( $unit =~ /minute/i || $unit =~ /min/i ) {
00645         $val *= 60;
00646     } elsif ( $unit =~ /second/i || $unit =~ /sec/i || $unit =~ /^s$/i ) {
00647         # do nothing
00648     } else {
00649         warn("Unrecognized time unit $unit.\nAssuming seconds.\n");
00650     }
00651     return $val;
00652     } elsif ( $t =~ /^(\d+)$/ ) {
00653     return $t;
00654     } else {
00655     warn("Unrecognized time interval: $t\n");
00656     return 0;
00657     }
00658 }
00659 
00660 =item before($time, $now)
00661 
00662 True if $now is less than $time. If $now is not specified, the value of time()
00663 is used.
00664 
00665 =cut
00666 
00667 sub before  { return (@_==2) ? $_[1] < $_[0] : time < $_[0] }
00668 
00669 =item after($time, $now)
00670 
00671 True if $now is greater than $time. If $now is not specified, the value of time()
00672 is used.
00673 
00674 =cut
00675 
00676 sub after   { return (@_==2) ? $_[1] > $_[0] : time > $_[0] }
00677 
00678 =item between($start, $end, $now)
00679 
00680 True if $now is greater than or equal to $start and less than or equal to $end.
00681 If $now is not specified, the value of time() is used.
00682 
00683 =cut
00684 
00685 sub between { my $t = (@_==3) ? $_[2] : time; return $t >= $_[0] && $t <= $_[1] }
00686 
00687 =back
00688 
00689 =cut

00695 sub writeLog($$@) {
00696     my ($ce, $facility, @message) = @_;
00697     unless ($ce->{webworkFiles}->{logs}->{$facility}) {
00698         warn "There is no log file for the $facility facility defined.\n";
00699         return;
00700     }
00701     my $logFile = $ce->{webworkFiles}->{logs}->{$facility};
00702     surePathToFile($ce->{webworkDirs}->{root}, $logFile);
00703     local *LOG;
00704     if (open LOG, ">>", $logFile) {
00705         print LOG "[", time2str("%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %Y", time), "] @message\n";
00706         close LOG;
00707     } else {
00708         warn "failed to open $logFile for writing: $!";
00709     }
00710 }
00711 
00712 sub writeCourseLog($$@) {
00713     my ($ce, $facility, @message) = @_;
00714     unless ($ce->{courseFiles}->{logs}->{$facility}) {
00715         warn "There is no course log file for the $facility facility defined.\n";
00716         return;
00717     }
00718     my $logFile = $ce->{courseFiles}->{logs}->{$facility};
00719     surePathToFile($ce->{courseDirs}->{root}, $logFile);
00720     local *LOG;
00721     if (open LOG, ">>", $logFile) {
00722         print LOG "[", time2str("%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %Y", time), "] @message\n";
00723         close LOG;
00724     } else {
00725         warn "failed to open $logFile for writing: $!";
00726     }
00727 }
00728 
00729 # $ce - a WeBWork::CourseEnvironment object
00730 # $function - fully qualified function name
00731 # $details - any information, do not use the characters '[' or ']'
00732 # $beginEnd - the string "begin", "intermediate", or "end"
00733 # use the intermediate step begun or completed for INTERMEDIATE
00734 # use an empty string for $details when calling for END
00735 # Information printed in format:
00736 # [formatted date & time ] processID unixTime BeginEnd $function  $details
00737 sub writeTimingLogEntry($$$$) {
00738     my ($ce, $function, $details, $beginEnd) = @_;
00739     $beginEnd = ($beginEnd eq "begin") ? ">" : ($beginEnd eq "end") ? "<" : "-";
00740     writeLog($ce, "timing", "$$ ".time." $beginEnd $function [$details]");
00741 }

00746 ## Utility function to trim whitespace off the start and end of its input
00747 sub trim_spaces {
00748     my $in = shift;
00749     return '' unless $in;  # skip blank spaces
00750     $in =~ s/^\s*(.*?)\s*$/$1/;
00751     return($in);
00752 }
00753 sub list2hash(@) {
00754     map {$_ => "0"} @_;
00755 }

00757 sub refBaseType($) {
00758     my $ref = shift;
00759     $ref =~ m/(\w+)\(/; # this might not be robust...
00760     return $1;
00761 }
00762 
00763 sub ref2string($;$);
00764 sub ref2string($;$) {
00765     my $ref = shift;
00766     my $dontExpand = shift || {};
00767     my $refType = ref $ref;
00768     my $result;
00769     if ($refType and not $dontExpand->{$refType}) {
00770         my $baseType = refBaseType($ref);
00771         $result .= '<font size="1" color="grey">' . $refType;
00772         $result .= " ($baseType)" if $baseType and $refType ne $baseType;
00773         $result .= ":</font><br>";
00774         $result .= '<table border="1" cellpadding="2">';
00775         if ($baseType eq "HASH") {
00776             my %hash = %$ref;
00777             foreach (sort keys %hash) {
00778                 $result .= '<tr valign="top">';
00779                 $result .= "<td>$_</td>";
00780                 $result .= "<td>" . ref2string($hash{$_}, $dontExpand) . "</td>";
00781                 $result .= "</tr>";
00782             }
00783         } elsif ($baseType eq "ARRAY") {
00784             my @array = @$ref;
00785             # special case for Problem, Set, and User objects, which are defined
00786             # using lists and contain a @FIELDS package variable:
00787             no strict 'refs';
00788             my @FIELDS = eval { @{$refType."::FIELDS"} };
00789             use strict 'refs';
00790             undef @FIELDS unless scalar @FIELDS == scalar @array and not $@;
00791             foreach (0 .. $#array) {
00792                 $result .= '<tr valign="top">';
00793                 $result .= "<td>$_</td>";
00794                 $result .= "<td>".$FIELDS[$_]."</td>" if @FIELDS;
00795                 $result .= "<td>" . ref2string($array[$_], $dontExpand) . "</td>";
00796                 $result .= "</tr>";
00797             }
00798         } elsif ($baseType eq "SCALAR") {
00799             my $scalar = $$ref;
00800             $result .= '<tr valign="top">';
00801             $result .= "<td>$scalar</td>";
00802             $result .= "</tr>";
00803         } else {
00804             # perhaps a coderef? in any case, i don't feel like dealing with it!
00805             $result .= '<tr valign="top">';
00806             $result .= "<td>$ref</td>";
00807             $result .= "</tr>";
00808         }
00809         $result .= "</table>"
00810     } else {
00811         $result .= defined $ref ? $ref : '<font color="red">undef</font>';
00812     }   
00813 }

00834 sub decodeAnswers($) {
00835     my $serialized = shift;
00836     return unless defined $serialized and $serialized;
00837     my $array_ref = eval{ Storable::thaw($serialized) };
00838     if ($@) {
00839         warn "problem fetching answers -- possibly left over from base64 days. Not to worry -- press preview or submit and this will go away  permanently for this question.   $@";
00840         return ();
00841     } else {
00842         return @{$array_ref};
00843     }
00844 }
00845 
00846 sub encodeAnswers(\%\@) {
00847     my %hash = %{shift()};
00848     my @order = @{shift()};
00849     my @ordered_hash = ();
00850     foreach my $key (@order) {
00851         push @ordered_hash, $key, $hash{$key};
00852     }
00853     return Storable::freeze( \@ordered_hash);
00854 
00855 }

00886 sub max(@) {
00887     my $soFar;
00888     foreach my $item (@_) {
00889         $soFar = $item unless defined $soFar;
00890         if ($item > $soFar) {
00891             $soFar = $item;
00892         }
00893     }
00894     return defined $soFar ? $soFar : 0;
00895 }
00896 
00897 sub pretty_print_rh($) {
00898     my $rh = shift;
00899     foreach my $key (sort keys %{$rh})  {
00900         warn "  $key => ",$rh->{$key},"\n";
00901     }
00902 }

00904 sub cryptPassword($) {
00905     my ($clearPassword) = @_;
00906     my $salt = join("", ('.','/','0'..'9','A'..'Z','a'..'z')[rand 64, rand 64]);
00907     my $cryptPassword = crypt($clearPassword, $salt);
00908     return $cryptPassword;
00909 }
00910 
00911 # from the Perl Cookbook, first edition, page 25:
00912 sub dequote($) {
00913     local $_ = shift;
00914     my ($white, $leader); # common whitespace and common leading string
00915     if (/^\s*(?:([^\w\s]+)(\s*).*\n)(?:\s*\1\2?.*\n)+$/) {
00916         ($white, $leader) = ($2, quotemeta($1));
00917     } else {
00918         ($white, $leader) = (/^(\s+)/, '');
00919     }
00920     s/^\s*?$leader(?:$white)?//gm;
00921     return $_;
00922 }
00923 
00924 sub undefstr($@) {
00925     map { defined $_ ? $_ : $_[0] } @_[1..$#_];
00926 }

00929 # shuffle an array in place
00930 # Perl Cookbook, Recipe 4.17. Randomizing an Array
00931 sub fisher_yates_shuffle {
00932     my $array = shift;
00933     my $i;
00934     for ($i = @$array; --$i; ) {
00935         my $j = int rand ($i+1);
00936         next if $i == $j;
00937         @$array[$i,$j] = @$array[$j,$i];
00938     }
00939 }
00940 
00941 sub constituency_hash {
00942     my $hash = {};
00943     @$hash{@_} = ();
00944     return $hash;
00945 }

00947 ################################################################################
00948 # Sorting
00949 ################################################################################
00950 
00951 # p. 101, Camel, 3rd ed.
00952 # The <=> and cmp operators return -1 if the left operand is less than the
00953 # right operand, 0 if they are equal, and +1 if the left operand is greater
00954 # than the right operand.
00955 #
00956 # FIXME: I've added the ability to do multiple field sorts, below; I'm 
00957 #    leaving this code, commented out, in case there's a good reason to 
00958 #    revert to this and do multiple field sorts differently.  -glr 2007/03/05
00959 # sub sortByName($@) {
00960 #   my ($field, @items) = @_;
00961 #   return sort {
00962 #       my @aParts = split m/(?<=\D)(?=\d)|(?<=\d)(?=\D)/, defined $field ? $a->$field : $a;
00963 #       my @bParts = split m/(?<=\D)(?=\d)|(?<=\d)(?=\D)/, defined $field ? $b->$field : $b;
00964 #       while (@aParts and @bParts) {
00965 #           my $aPart = shift @aParts;
00966 #           my $bPart = shift @bParts;
00967 #           my $aNumeric = $aPart =~ m/^\d*$/;
00968 #           my $bNumeric = $bPart =~ m/^\d*$/;
00969 
00970 #           # numbers should come before words
00971 #           return -1 if     $aNumeric and not $bNumeric;
00972 #           return +1 if not $aNumeric and     $bNumeric;
00973 
00974 #           # both have the same type
00975 #           if ($aNumeric and $bNumeric) {
00976 #               next if $aPart == $bPart; # check next pair
00977 #               return $aPart <=> $bPart; # compare numerically
00978 #           } else {
00979 #               next if $aPart eq $bPart; # check next pair
00980 #               return $aPart cmp $bPart; # compare lexicographically
00981 #           }
00982 #       }
00983 #       return +1 if @aParts; # a has more sections, should go second
00984 #       return -1 if @bParts; # a had fewer sections, should go first
00985 #   } @items;
00986 # }
00987 
00988 sub sortByName($@) {
00989     my ($field, @items) = @_;
00990 
00991     my %itemsByIndex = ();
00992     if ( ref( $field ) eq 'ARRAY' ) {
00993         foreach my $item ( @items ) {
00994             my $key = '';
00995             foreach ( @$field ) {
00996                     $key .= $item->$_;  # in this case we assume 
00997             }                           #    all entries in @$field
00998             $itemsByIndex{$key} = $item;  #  are defined.
00999             }
01000     } else {
01001         %itemsByIndex = map {(defined $field)?$_->$field:$_ => $_} @items;
01002     }
01003 
01004     my @sKeys = sort {
01005         my @aParts = split m/(?<=\D)(?=\d)|(?<=\d)(?=\D)/, $a;
01006         my @bParts = split m/(?<=\D)(?=\d)|(?<=\d)(?=\D)/, $b;
01007 
01008         while (@aParts and @bParts) {
01009             my $aPart = shift @aParts;
01010             my $bPart = shift @bParts;
01011             my $aNumeric = $aPart =~ m/^\d*$/;
01012             my $bNumeric = $bPart =~ m/^\d*$/;
01013 
01014             # numbers should come before words
01015             return -1 if     $aNumeric and not $bNumeric;
01016             return +1 if not $aNumeric and     $bNumeric;
01017 
01018             # both have the same type
01019             if ($aNumeric and $bNumeric) {
01020                 next if $aPart == $bPart; # check next pair
01021                 return $aPart <=> $bPart; # compare numerically
01022             } else {
01023                 next if $aPart eq $bPart; # check next pair
01024                 return $aPart cmp $bPart; # compare lexicographically
01025             }
01026         }
01027         return +1 if @aParts; # a has more sections, should go second
01028         return -1 if @bParts; # a had fewer sections, should go first
01029     } (keys %itemsByIndex);
01030 
01031     return map{$itemsByIndex{$_}} @sKeys;
01032 }
01033

01035 # Validate strings and labels
01036 ################################################################################
01037 
01038 sub not_blank ($) {     # check that a string exists and is not blank
01039     my $str = shift;
01040     return( defined($str) and $str =~/\S/ );
01041 }
01042 
01043 ###########################################################
01044     # If things have worked so far determine if the file might be accompanied by auxiliary files
01045     
01046     #
01047 sub has_aux_files ($) { #  determine whether a question has auxiliary files
01048                         # a path ending in    foo/foo.pg  is assumed to contain auxilliary files
01049     my $path = shift;
01050     if ( not_blank($path) ) {
01051             my ($dir, $prob) = $path =~ m|([^/]+)/([^/]+)\.pg$|;  # must be a problem file ending in .pg
01052             return 1 if (defined($dir) and defined ($prob) and $dir eq $prob);
01053     } else {
01054         warn "This subroutine cannot handle empty paths: |$path|",caller();
01055     }
01056     return 0;    # no aux files with this .pg file
01057 
01058 }
